title: Cut the Array
statementHtml:
You are given an array of nn non-negative integers [a1,a2,…,an][a1,a2,…,an].

Your task is to cut it into three non-empty parts: a prefix, a middle part, and a suffix. Formally, you need to choose two integers ll and rr such that 1≤l<r<n1≤l<r<n, and obtain three parts:

Let s1,s2,s3s1,s2,s3 be the remainders of the sums of these parts modulo 33. In other words:

Your task is to find such boundaries ll and rr that either all numbers s1,s2,s3s1,s2,s3 are different, or all numbers s1,s2,s3s1,s2,s3 are the same.
inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤10001≤t≤1000) — the number of test cases.

Each test case consists of two lines:

  • the first line contains a single integer nn (3≤n≤403≤n≤40);
  • the second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (0≤ai≤400≤ai≤40).
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, if a suitable pair of integers ll and rr (1≤l<r<n1≤l<r<n) exists, output these two integers (if there are multiple suitable pairs, you can output any of them). Otherwise, output two integers equal to 00.
noteHtml:
Consider the examples from the statement:

  • in the first example, the array is cut into parts [1,2,3][1,2,3], [4,5][4,5], [6][6]; s1=s2=s3=0s1=s2=s3=0;
  • in the second example, there is no suitable cut;
  • in the third example, the array is cut into parts [2][2], [1][1], [0][0]; s1=2s1=2, s2=1s2=1, s3=0s3=0;
  • in the fourth example, the array is cut into parts [7,2][7,2], [6,2][6,2], [4][4]; s1=0s1=0, s2=2s2=2, s3=1s3=1.
tutorialHtml:
Of course, we can iterate through the positions l and r, and then check if we get a valid cut. However, there is a simpler solution.

Let's try to rephrase the condition "either all numbers s1,s2,s3 are different, or all numbers s1,s2,s3 are the same". Since these are remainders when divided by 3, their sum will be equal to 0 modulo 3:

  • if they are all equal to 0, 1, or 2, then their sum is divisible by 3;
  • otherwise, one of them is 0, another is 1, and the third is 2, and their sum equals 3.

On the other hand, if s1+s2+s3 is equal to 0 modulo 3, then there are two possible cases:

  • either s1=s2, in which case s3 will be equal to them (otherwise their sum would not be divisible by 3);
  • or s1≠s2, then s3=3−s1−s2, and regardless of the values of s1 and s2, s3 will differ from them.

Thus, if the sum of the array is not divisible by 3, then there is no suitable cut; and if it is divisible by 3, then any cut will be valid.
